data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this some days ago on Avanza,  Placera forum. Google translation from Swedish: The next step towards the mine is not a political process The Land and Environmental Court in Umeå will handle Beowulf's environmental application for Kallak. The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) in the Environmental Court is fundamentally different from the process for a mining concession. Mining concession (Mineral Act): This process has historically had a significant political element. In the event of disagreement between the Mining Authority and the County Administrative Board, or in the event of appeals of principle, the decision ends up with the government. The Sami community then appealed the government's decision to the Supreme Administrative Court, formerly the Government Court. EIA and environmental assessment (Environmental Code): The assessment in a land and environmental court is a purely legal process. The court in Umeå assesses whether the application and its EIA meet the law's strict environmental requirements and technical specifications. The court is independent and does not take political considerations into account in its ruling. In summary, the application for a mining concession is a mixture of the exercise of authority and political decision-making, while the environmental assessment is a strictly legal process in court. This is important because the time frames used by the court are tight to avoid delay from any party. The slightly exhausted sentiment on this debate page may be able to be made to look up: Now the delaying tactics will end, the court sets the time frames. Kallak will be an open pit mine. You will have cheap mining costs, ore clean from contaminants and a final product with almost 70% pure iron to sell at premium prices. If Beowulf raises capital via the financing plan, it can submit an EIA for Kallak this year. Various consulting firms are working on their respective field measurements. An interesting competition is arising internally, which of the two projects Grafintec in Finland or Kallak in Sweden will be closest in terms of cash flow? I must admit that I have probably underestimated the work that has been done during the 20s at Grafintec. Grafintec is not, at the moment, running a mining start-up with its longer processing times, but the start-up of an industrial plant for anode manufacturing with support from the Finnish state both financially and in permit issues. Should we guess that Kallak has its EIA approved at about the same time that Grafintec's demo plant has proven credible for prospective car battery customers, the second half of -27? Will Beowulf let partners into Kallak already at the end of -26 in exchange for them carrying Beowulf through the EIA and drilling up the tonnage, e.g. 25% of Kallak in exchange for a couple of times larger tonnage after drilling? Or do you wait until after the EIA to get more out of a partner? Should Grafintec pay Kallak or Kallak pay Grafinte

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: One more thing about the Finnish business: The Chinese dominate the battery market, but in Finland they are making a chess move: The Chinese want to avoid EU's customs duties/tariffs, so they are establishing themselves with a large factory in Finland in one of the support areas identified by the state, namly the town of Kotka. And guess who has booked the land as their neighbor. :-) - Yes, it is Grafintec. By the way, other players in the battery industry are also there, attracted there by the conscious policy of the Finnish state and the EU. https://battery-news.de/en/2025/03/28/construction-of-finnish-cathode-material-plant-to-begin/

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: I read Pocko's last 20 posts on this page. -You have my full respect.  I sold when I believed on legal grounds that the mining opponents would succeed in postponing the mining start for a long time. I saw the Vardar project as a sign that K Budge saw the matter the same way. The upcoming financing is based on the Finnish operations in terms of value, the sale of Vardar is a smaller part in terms of value. I think it is wise to use relative valuation in this phase in a sharp situation, e.g. Talgas' market value. However, the valuation against other iron mines with similar products is more complicated due to different costs to reach the refined product. All other things being equal, the relative valuation of building an anode plant seems easier to value in my opinion as there are fewer moving parts that can go in other directions than expected. That said, perhaps my headline about minimal dilution in Beowulf should be given a self-critical evaluation: A dilution in Grafintec is a dilution in what , maybe, takes us fastest towards a cash flow? Both Kallak and Grafintec can be used through a partnership agreement with the decisive intention of generating cash for the other project. We have been used to only talking about Kallak, perhaps we need to think about that matter? I see leverage in the upcoming year: First a successful financing, then a construction of the pilot plant in Finland and the submission of the application for an environmental permit for Kallak. Both of these steps are value-creating. Taken together enough for me to reevaluate the situation and being invested here again.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: News that brings the company closer to cash flow is probably considered by many in the market as value-creating. Events that extend the distance to cash flow show the opposite. Is it too simple? The processing concession gave Beowulf exclusive rights to Kallak's ore. It gave a value boost. The delaying tactics of the mining opponents resulted in lost time and also worse finances for Beowulf. Everything is in Beowulf's chart. Now they want to make new financing in order to be able to submit an EIA, with minimal dilution. If that financing is successful in the spring, I believe it will be considered value-creating. I think it will be visible in the chart. Despite the fact that there are 2 years to cash flow. As mentioned, Talga, which is at the end of its demo phase for its facility in Luleå, is valued at 11 times Beowulf's market value.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this on Avanza, Placera (Excuse fore the Google tranlation.): In the Finnish financial environment, the "base interest rate" is equivalent to what is called, peruskorko, Here are the details of the base interest rate in Finland: Current level (January 2026): The base interest rate is set at 2.25% for the period from January 1 to June 30, 2026. Definition: It is an administrative interest rate set by the Finnish Ministry of Finance twice a year (in June and December). Calculation basis: It is based on the average of 12-month market interest rates (Euribor) over the previous three months, rounded to the nearest quarter percentage point. That is, Grafintec can borrow 7 million Euros with a good margin at 1% interest ( 3% under the current interet rate, 1% as a floor) . The sale of shares in Grafintec will bring in 5 million Euros. "Beowulf is expected to retain a significant majority holding post the equity raise." The financing of Grafintec will enable the company to demonstrate the scaling up of the company's processes. "Successful completion of this phase in the project's development will enable Grafintec to secure off-take agreements with end users, underpinning the financing of the full commercial plant." This phase is estimated to take 1.5-2 years after financing. Beowulf has an interested actor who is making a DD to buy the Vardar project for 4 million Euros. Here we may get the first announcement of the financing plan. This means that Beowulf makes 5+4 million Euros visible for its operations. In addition, the subsidiary will receive a loan with 1% interest. (The 5 million in Grafintec will be diluted to a degree we see after the share sale in the company has been made.) Total: Beowulf's two operations after the sale of Vardar will receive cash of 4+5+7 million Euros, i.e. 97 million SEK plus 75 million in loans at 1% interest. Beowulf's market value before the results of this financing are completed is 88 million SEK. Beowulf has almost 60 million shares before the financing. If the lender redeems the warrants, the number increases by 4,329,004.

data.content: Love turnarounds. Beowulf now has two substantial projects with crucial news during the year, market cap in Sweden under 100 million SEK. It was many years ago last time, I participated in Sweden with the signature "gruvgunnar" on Avanza and Redeye. My signature on Avanza disappeared when they took a break with the site, then someone else took the signature. :-) . Now  I will write under "resonera". I liked the bridge financing, especially the paragraph that the lender has the right to subscribe for warrants at a price close to today's price. This indicates that the lender believes that Beowulf's financing strategy will succeed. I have chosen to believe in that signal from the lender. I bought some in Sthlm. My research has so far been around the Finnish business which in its current form has developed a different technology to produce the refined product. Smart to buy time by choosing to buy the raw material first. Will be a race against Talga's business in Luleå. Talga's market cap is 11 times larger than Beowulf's. Although Beowulf has one more leg: They will submit their application for an environmental permit for Kallak at the end of -26. That court will not accept delays from individual actors. - It will be exciting to follow. :-)

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this in Sweden today. Google translation. Today's release and the new company presentation can only be described as transparent. Surely many different angles can be given after reading through. One thought from me is that the thing that the CEO can influence is the Vardar sale. If there are no weather obstacles to the buyer's DD, a deal should be concluded so that cash comes to the company. The point is to reduce uncertainty and minimize costs associated with the bridge loan. Should Grafintec's appeal of the rejected application for 131.5 million Euros be successful, the world will be turned upside down in an instant. Business Finland's regulations are such that the upcoming loan may not be used for the same costs as the tax relief, which is why they are expected to be distributed to the demo plant, or later to the construction of the production plant. What is a mining company worth that has submitted a full environmental application and is thus open to assessment by competing majors in the market for DIR ore? Deals can range from the simple conclusion of a deal where a larger company takes, for example, 25% of Kallak in exchange for carrying Beowulf in the meantime and giving the company a couple of times larger tonnage than today. On the other side, there is a take-off agreement where a company ensures that it will buy all finished products from Kallak. In between, various structures can be considered. When I entered Beowulf perhaps 11-12 years ago, the price was 22 öre. There were more shares and Kallak was valued at 100 million SEK in crisis. Now we have a processing concession, an environmental application for Kallak to be completed during the year and another business leg in the form of Grafintech which will probably enter cash flow before Kallak. These two companies are valued at 40 million each? In all simplicity, I think that the risk of a slightly lower price on a Vardar financing can be compensated by perhaps a multiple of the market valuation? Maybe it could even affect the outcome of a smart construction deal? Looking forward to future news.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: In recent years, Talga has received extensive financial support in the form of direct grants and favorable loan financing, primarily from the EU and the Swedish state, to develop its graphite extraction and production of battery anodes. Here are the key occasions when the company was granted support: 1. EU Innovation Fund (October 2024) Talga was awarded a grant of €70 million (just over SEK 800 million) from the EU Innovation Fund for the construction of its commercial anode refinery in Luleå. This support is earmarked for technical solutions that contribute to the EU's climate goals and reduce dependence on imported raw materials. 2. The Industrial Leap (Industriklivet) – Swedish Energy Agency (October 2025) The Swedish government, through the Swedish Energy Agency, granted support of SEK 82.6 million within the framework of The Industrial Leap. The purpose of the grant is to co-finance a project for the sustainable production of active anode materials from both natural and recycled graphite, to be validated on a near-industrial scale. 3. European Investment Bank (EIB) (June 2023 & January 2026) While technically a loan rather than a pure grant (subsidized loan), the EIB has approved debt financing of €150 million for the Vittangi Anode Project. This financing is seen as a central part of the EU's effort to secure critical minerals and was recently re-confirmed as a cornerstone of the company's financing plan ahead of the production start. 4. Strategic Status under the CRMA (March 2025) In 2025, Talga's graphite project was designated a "Strategic Project" under the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA). While this does not represent a direct cash injection in the form of a grant, it provides the company with prioritized access to financing opportunities and accelerated permitting processes throughout the Union. Paragraph 2 is more Sweden-related, Grafintec is, in the Finnish enviroment, seeking the previously mentioned loan at, in practice, 1% interest of 70 million SEK and a directed issue in Grafintec of 50 million SEK to build its demo facility. From there, further support is sought. Grafintec is actively working within the framework of the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA). Grafintec has expressed a clear intention to apply for status as a Strategic Project for its graphite anode material (GAMP) facility in Finland. The deadline for applying for this expired the other day, 15 January. It is reasonable that self-financing plus a loan during the year will be something that will start the demo facility for anode manufacturing and trigger support within these frameworks for the construction of the final production facility. Investing in Beowulf is perhaps to have an idea of ​​the possibilities for external support for graphite as anodes in batteries.

data.author: Pocko
data.content: The market in Sweden has always been incredibly volatile in comparison to the UK market - UK investors have been bitten numerous times by this company, and are therefore more cautious. In respect of Vardar, of which I have often been critical, get it over the line. What parameters have been set for the third parties due diligence? Surely there is an actual date to work towards which is normal practice for any sale. As for Grafintec? It’s a limited company subject to minimal financial reporting, unlike BEM which is a PLC - so as I’ve stated previously, watch this space for it essentially being taken private - Let’s see what equity the company cedes in order to raise capital?

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: You are right, Pocko, actual action is the only thing that matters. What does that mean, to me?: 1. Finalize the financing plan regarding Beowulf's ability to submit its EIA without dilution through the sale of the Vardar project. 2. Make a private placement in the subsidiary Grafintec for 5 million Euros and support its efforts to obtain 7 million Euros as a loan with a subsidized interest rate of 1%. And - let's see the start of a demo plant for anode manufacturing for batteries in Kotka, Finland. I see that over 70% of the shares are on Nasdaq in Stockholm, ticker BEO. There are just over 60 million shares at a valuation that would be if the financing were not successful. But in Sthlm, the last few weeks the lows have been higher every time. Upward breakout in progress?

data.author: Pocko
data.content: I’ve been quite clear in my posts of the last few years about the work to be done and the timelines, and repeatedly been accused of negativity? The company has been the subject of political chicanery for sure, but investors have also been repeatedly misled either deliberately or through the naivety of the board that quite frankly, have profited handsomely over the years. There is still little to show for the £25 million spent in the last 10-years. The last significant RNS would, for any normal company look on paper at least, to be a huge step forward. However, until the company actually produces anything of note, it’s just words. I hope to be proved wrong moving forward.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: The construction of Easpring’s new battery materials plant in Keltakallio, Kotka, has entered its most intensive phase as of early 2026. Here are the latest local updates: Installation Phase: As of early 2026, the installation of advanced production equipment, such as kiln systems, is underway. Over 1,000 containers of equipment are arriving via the Port of Hamina-Kotka. On-site Workforce: There are currently around 800 construction workers and installers on-site. Many of the specialists for the machinery installation have arrived from China. Key Permit Granted: On February 9, 2026, Tukes (the Finnish Safety and Chemicals Agency) announced that the factory has been granted its chemical safety permit, a critical milestone for future operations. Building Status: The structural frame of the main building (approx. 36,000 sqm) was completed in late 2025. Timeline: Summer 2026: Planned start for the first sample production. 2027: Expected start of full commercial production.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: If you believe that Beowulf and/or Grafintec will finance their respective projects to complete the EIA for Kallak and/or to build a pilot plant for graphite in Finland, it might be wise to find an entry point. It would be reasonable to choose an opportunity like now when the lender is selling its shares in Stockholm. If you don't believe this, but want to participate after the financing of one or both projects is at home, then you can buy afterwards. I left Beowulf because I felt that the Vardar acquisition diluted the company. I missed out on the upside when Beowulf received the processing concession.  No big profits or losses. - But, I take responsibility for my purchases and sales. Financing is no walk in the park. We'll see how it goes. I prefer a solution that gives Beowulf a firmer backbone, a deal with a major before the EIA is completed. As I mentioned earlier, for example, a solution with 25% of Kallak's tonnage in exchange for a major drilling up 2-3 times the JORC tonnage and carrying Beowulf through the EIA. The correct name in Sweden of that major is always LKAB, that would cause an explosion in the share price. But another name will do just fine. The conditions will not be the same as after an approved EIA, but it affects the possibility of other external public financing and permitting. A cake that is 2-3 times larger is better than this ad hoc situation. There are surely other proposals that are better. For example, that the current financing is presented and a major can come in when the EIA is complete. :-)

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: This is a AI-generated answer to this question: "Which iron mines during start-up have received support because they have high-grade iron ore as a product?" The search was in Swedish. In Sweden, startups or restart projects focusing on high-grade iron ore (crucial for green steel production) have primarily received support through climate-transition funds and EU innovation programs. Here are the specific projects and the types of support they have received: 1. Nordic Iron Ore (Blötberget) This project aims to produce an ultra-high-grade concentrate (>68% Fe) suitable for Direct Reduction (DR) plants. Support: They participated in the EU-funded X-MINE project under the Horizon 2020 program. This provided funding for advanced sensing technology to improve ore sorting and quality. Status: They are actively positioning themselves to benefit from the Critical Raw Materials Act due to their high-grade product profile. 2. GRANGEX (Grängesberg) GRANGEX is working to restart the Grängesberg mine with a focus on fossil-free, ultra-high-grade iron ore. Support: They have received innovation grants from Vinnova (Sweden’s Innovation Agency) for projects related to sustainable mining technologies. Strategic Debt: While not a direct grant, they have secured support structures from international partners (like Anglo American) which are often facilitated by the Swedish Export Credit Corporation (SEK) and EKN guarantees for green transition projects. 3. LKAB (The Hybrit & ReeMAP Projects) While LKAB is established, their "startup" divisions for fossil-free sponge iron are treated as new industrial ventures. Support: This is the largest recipient of public funds. They received over SEK 3 billion from The Industrial Leap (Industriklivet) via the Swedish Energy Agency. EU Funding: They also secured major funding from the EU Innovation Fund for the demonstration plant in Gällivare, specifically because high-grade ore is the feedstock for the fossil-free process. 4. Kaunis Iron (Pajala) Though a restart of an existing site, their focus on high-grade concentrate (69% Fe) has made them eligible for specific regional development support. Support: They have received Regional Investment Aid from Tillväxtverket to build infrastructure that supports high-efficiency processing. Why does "High-Grade" trigger funding? Public funding is currently restricted for "standard" mining but available for high-grade projects because: Direct Reduction (DR) Compatibility: Standard blast furnaces are being replaced by DR towers, which require ore with >67% Fe. Decarbonization: High-grade ore reduces the energy needed in the smelting process, a key goal of the European Green Deal.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: As Beowulf have mentioned in different releases there are several sources of financing. To finalize the environmental permit application for Kallak (Jokkmokk Iron) in 2026, Beowulf Mining can utilize specific Swedish grant forms that fund the technical investigations and environmental impact assessments (EIA) required by law. While Swedish agencies do not fund the "writing" of an application, they provide significant capital for the studies and technology designs that form the core of the application. 1. Industriklivet (The Industrial Leap) – Feasibility Studies Managed by the Swedish Energy Agency, this is the most critical source for funding the technical planning of the mine. Target: Funding for feasibility studies that lead to large-scale industrial decarbonization. Application for Kallak: Beowulf can apply for grants to design a fossil-free mining process (e.g., electric haulage, carbon-neutral ore processing). Since the environmental court requires detailed plans on how emissions are minimized, the cost of these technical designs (essential for the EIA) can be covered up to 50%. Purpose: To prove that the mine can operate without fossil fuels, a key requirement for permit approval in 2026. 2. Metals & Minerals – Feasibility Calls (Impact Innovation) This is a new, high-priority program for 2026, co-funded by Vinnova and the Swedish Energy Agency. Target: Accelerating permitting processes and sustainable extraction. Application for Kallak: Beowulf can apply for funding for specific environmental innovation studies required for the permit, such as: Water Purification: Developing circular water systems to ensure zero harmful discharge into local water systems (a major hurdle for Kallak). Waste Rock Management: Studies on repurposing waste rock into construction material to minimize the tailings footprint. Deadline: A major call closes on February 3, 2026. 3. Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA) – Strategic Project Status Under new EU regulations active in 2026, Beowulf can apply through Vinnova or the Ministry of Climate and Enterprise to have Kallak designated as a "Strategic Project." The Benefit: Strategic projects gain access to fast-track permitting (limited to 27 months) and specific financial support tools to complete the final environmental and social impact studies required by the EU. Financial Link: This status unlocks easier access to EIB (European Investment Bank) loans and national guarantees specifically for the final permitting stages. 4. Regional Growth Grants (Region Norrbotten & Tillväxtverket) Regional funds are available for companies that drive the "Green Transition" in Northern Sweden. Application for Kallak: These funds can be used for the social and community aspects of the environmental application. This includes funding for consultation processes with the local community and the Sami reindeer herding districts (Sámiid Ædnan), which is a mandatory and costly part of the Swedish permitting pr

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this some days ago on Avanza,  Placera forum. Google translation from Swedish: The next step towards the mine is not a political process The Land and Environmental Court in Umeå will handle Beowulf's environmental application for Kallak. The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) in the Environmental Court is fundamentally different from the process for a mining concession. Mining concession (Mineral Act): This process has historically had a significant political element. In the event of disagreement between the Mining Authority and the County Administrative Board, or in the event of appeals of principle, the decision ends up with the government. The Sami community then appealed the government's decision to the Supreme Administrative Court, formerly the Government Court. EIA and environmental assessment (Environmental Code): The assessment in a land and environmental court is a purely legal process. The court in Umeå assesses whether the application and its EIA meet the law's strict environmental requirements and technical specifications. The court is independent and does not take political considerations into account in its ruling. In summary, the application for a mining concession is a mixture of the exercise of authority and political decision-making, while the environmental assessment is a strictly legal process in court. This is important because the time frames used by the court are tight to avoid delay from any party. The slightly exhausted sentiment on this debate page may be able to be made to look up: Now the delaying tactics will end, the court sets the time frames. Kallak will be an open pit mine. You will have cheap mining costs, ore clean from contaminants and a final product with almost 70% pure iron to sell at premium prices. If Beowulf raises capital via the financing plan, it can submit an EIA for Kallak this year. Various consulting firms are working on their respective field measurements. An interesting competition is arising internally, which of the two projects Grafintec in Finland or Kallak in Sweden will be closest in terms of cash flow? I must admit that I have probably underestimated the work that has been done during the 20s at Grafintec. Grafintec is not, at the moment, running a mining start-up with its longer processing times, but the start-up of an industrial plant for anode manufacturing with support from the Finnish state both financially and in permit issues. Should we guess that Kallak has its EIA approved at about the same time that Grafintec's demo plant has proven credible for prospective car battery customers, the second half of -27? Will Beowulf let partners into Kallak already at the end of -26 in exchange for them carrying Beowulf through the EIA and drilling up the tonnage, e.g. 25% of Kallak in exchange for a couple of times larger tonnage after drilling? Or do you wait until after the EIA to get more out of a partner? Should Grafintec pay Kallak or Kallak pay Grafinte

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: One more thing about the Finnish business: The Chinese dominate the battery market, but in Finland they are making a chess move: The Chinese want to avoid EU's customs duties/tariffs, so they are establishing themselves with a large factory in Finland in one of the support areas identified by the state, namly the town of Kotka. And guess who has booked the land as their neighbor. :-) - Yes, it is Grafintec. By the way, other players in the battery industry are also there, attracted there by the conscious policy of the Finnish state and the EU. https://battery-news.de/en/2025/03/28/construction-of-finnish-cathode-material-plant-to-begin/

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: I read Pocko's last 20 posts on this page. -You have my full respect.  I sold when I believed on legal grounds that the mining opponents would succeed in postponing the mining start for a long time. I saw the Vardar project as a sign that K Budge saw the matter the same way. The upcoming financing is based on the Finnish operations in terms of value, the sale of Vardar is a smaller part in terms of value. I think it is wise to use relative valuation in this phase in a sharp situation, e.g. Talgas' market value. However, the valuation against other iron mines with similar products is more complicated due to different costs to reach the refined product. All other things being equal, the relative valuation of building an anode plant seems easier to value in my opinion as there are fewer moving parts that can go in other directions than expected. That said, perhaps my headline about minimal dilution in Beowulf should be given a self-critical evaluation: A dilution in Grafintec is a dilution in what , maybe, takes us fastest towards a cash flow? Both Kallak and Grafintec can be used through a partnership agreement with the decisive intention of generating cash for the other project. We have been used to only talking about Kallak, perhaps we need to think about that matter? I see leverage in the upcoming year: First a successful financing, then a construction of the pilot plant in Finland and the submission of the application for an environmental permit for Kallak. Both of these steps are value-creating. Taken together enough for me to reevaluate the situation and being invested here again.

data.content: News that brings the company closer to cash flow is probably considered by many in the market as value-creating. Events that extend the distance to cash flow show the opposite. Is it too simple? The processing concession gave Beowulf exclusive rights to Kallak's ore. It gave a value boost. The delaying tactics of the mining opponents resulted in lost time and also worse finances for Beowulf. Everything is in Beowulf's chart. Now they want to make new financing in order to be able to submit an EIA, with minimal dilution. If that financing is successful in the spring, I believe it will be considered value-creating. I think it will be visible in the chart. Despite the fact that there are 2 years to cash flow. As mentioned, Talga, which is at the end of its demo phase for its facility in Luleå, is valued at 11 times Beowulf's market value.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this on Avanza, Placera (Excuse fore the Google tranlation.): In the Finnish financial environment, the "base interest rate" is equivalent to what is called, peruskorko, Here are the details of the base interest rate in Finland: Current level (January 2026): The base interest rate is set at 2.25% for the period from January 1 to June 30, 2026. Definition: It is an administrative interest rate set by the Finnish Ministry of Finance twice a year (in June and December). Calculation basis: It is based on the average of 12-month market interest rates (Euribor) over the previous three months, rounded to the nearest quarter percentage point. That is, Grafintec can borrow 7 million Euros with a good margin at 1% interest ( 3% under the current interet rate, 1% as a floor) . The sale of shares in Grafintec will bring in 5 million Euros. "Beowulf is expected to retain a significant majority holding post the equity raise." The financing of Grafintec will enable the company to demonstrate the scaling up of the company's processes. "Successful completion of this phase in the project's development will enable Grafintec to secure off-take agreements with end users, underpinning the financing of the full commercial plant." This phase is estimated to take 1.5-2 years after financing. Beowulf has an interested actor who is making a DD to buy the Vardar project for 4 million Euros. Here we may get the first announcement of the financing plan. This means that Beowulf makes 5+4 million Euros visible for its operations. In addition, the subsidiary will receive a loan with 1% interest. (The 5 million in Grafintec will be diluted to a degree we see after the share sale in the company has been made.) Total: Beowulf's two operations after the sale of Vardar will receive cash of 4+5+7 million Euros, i.e. 97 million SEK plus 75 million in loans at 1% interest. Beowulf's market value before the results of this financing are completed is 88 million SEK. Beowulf has almost 60 million shares before the financing. If the lender redeems the warrants, the number increases by 4,329,004.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: Wrote this in Sweden today. Google translation. Today's release and the new company presentation can only be described as transparent. Surely many different angles can be given after reading through. One thought from me is that the thing that the CEO can influence is the Vardar sale. If there are no weather obstacles to the buyer's DD, a deal should be concluded so that cash comes to the company. The point is to reduce uncertainty and minimize costs associated with the bridge loan. Should Grafintec's appeal of the rejected application for 131.5 million Euros be successful, the world will be turned upside down in an instant. Business Finland's regulations are such that the upcoming loan may not be used for the same costs as the tax relief, which is why they are expected to be distributed to the demo plant, or later to the construction of the production plant. What is a mining company worth that has submitted a full environmental application and is thus open to assessment by competing majors in the market for DIR ore? Deals can range from the simple conclusion of a deal where a larger company takes, for example, 25% of Kallak in exchange for carrying Beowulf in the meantime and giving the company a couple of times larger tonnage than today. On the other side, there is a take-off agreement where a company ensures that it will buy all finished products from Kallak. In between, various structures can be considered. When I entered Beowulf perhaps 11-12 years ago, the price was 22 öre. There were more shares and Kallak was valued at 100 million SEK in crisis. Now we have a processing concession, an environmental application for Kallak to be completed during the year and another business leg in the form of Grafintech which will probably enter cash flow before Kallak. These two companies are valued at 40 million each? In all simplicity, I think that the risk of a slightly lower price on a Vardar financing can be compensated by perhaps a multiple of the market valuation? Maybe it could even affect the outcome of a smart construction deal? Looking forward to future news.

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: In recent years, Talga has received extensive financial support in the form of direct grants and favorable loan financing, primarily from the EU and the Swedish state, to develop its graphite extraction and production of battery anodes. Here are the key occasions when the company was granted support: 1. EU Innovation Fund (October 2024) Talga was awarded a grant of €70 million (just over SEK 800 million) from the EU Innovation Fund for the construction of its commercial anode refinery in Luleå. This support is earmarked for technical solutions that contribute to the EU's climate goals and reduce dependence on imported raw materials. 2. The Industrial Leap (Industriklivet) – Swedish Energy Agency (October 2025) The Swedish government, through the Swedish Energy Agency, granted support of SEK 82.6 million within the framework of The Industrial Leap. The purpose of the grant is to co-finance a project for the sustainable production of active anode materials from both natural and recycled graphite, to be validated on a near-industrial scale. 3. European Investment Bank (EIB) (June 2023 & January 2026) While technically a loan rather than a pure grant (subsidized loan), the EIB has approved debt financing of €150 million for the Vittangi Anode Project. This financing is seen as a central part of the EU's effort to secure critical minerals and was recently re-confirmed as a cornerstone of the company's financing plan ahead of the production start. 4. Strategic Status under the CRMA (March 2025) In 2025, Talga's graphite project was designated a "Strategic Project" under the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA). While this does not represent a direct cash injection in the form of a grant, it provides the company with prioritized access to financing opportunities and accelerated permitting processes throughout the Union. Paragraph 2 is more Sweden-related, Grafintec is, in the Finnish enviroment, seeking the previously mentioned loan at, in practice, 1% interest of 70 million SEK and a directed issue in Grafintec of 50 million SEK to build its demo facility. From there, further support is sought. Grafintec is actively working within the framework of the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA). Grafintec has expressed a clear intention to apply for status as a Strategic Project for its graphite anode material (GAMP) facility in Finland. The deadline for applying for this expired the other day, 15 January. It is reasonable that self-financing plus a loan during the year will be something that will start the demo facility for anode manufacturing and trigger support within these frameworks for the construction of the final production facility. Investing in Beowulf is perhaps to have an idea of ​​the possibilities for external support for graphite as anodes in batteries.

data.content: I went modern and asked Google's AI three questions, one after the other. 1. What are the various forecasts for the supply of car batteries that require graphite anodes? Then: 2. Why are battery prices expected to fall? And then: 3. How does the price of refined graphite relate to this price drop for batteries? Don't know if the answers are identical when searching in English, but many suggestions for interesting sources on the subject. Summary: Battery prices are expected to fall and the price of graphite will rise.

data.author: Pocko
data.content: The market in Sweden has always been incredibly volatile in comparison to the UK market - UK investors have been bitten numerous times by this company, and are therefore more cautious. In respect of Vardar, of which I have often been critical, get it over the line. What parameters have been set for the third parties due diligence? Surely there is an actual date to work towards which is normal practice for any sale. As for Grafintec? It’s a limited company subject to minimal financial reporting, unlike BEM which is a PLC - so as I’ve stated previously, watch this space for it essentially being taken private - Let’s see what equity the company cedes in order to raise capital?

data.author: gruvgunnar
data.content: You are right, Pocko, actual action is the only thing that matters. What does that mean, to me?: 1. Finalize the financing plan regarding Beowulf's ability to submit its EIA without dilution through the sale of the Vardar project. 2. Make a private placement in the subsidiary Grafintec for 5 million Euros and support its efforts to obtain 7 million Euros as a loan with a subsidized interest rate of 1%. And - let's see the start of a demo plant for anode manufacturing for batteries in Kotka, Finland. I see that over 70% of the shares are on Nasdaq in Stockholm, ticker BEO. There are just over 60 million shares at a valuation that would be if the financing were not successful. But in Sthlm, the last few weeks the lows have been higher every time. Upward breakout in progress?

data.author: Pocko
data.content: I’ve been quite clear in my posts of the last few years about the work to be done and the timelines, and repeatedly been accused of negativity? The company has been the subject of political chicanery for sure, but investors have also been repeatedly misled either deliberately or through the naivety of the board that quite frankly, have profited handsomely over the years. There is still little to show for the £25 million spent in the last 10-years. The last significant RNS would, for any normal company look on paper at least, to be a huge step forward. However, until the company actually produces anything of note, it’s just words. I hope to be proved wrong moving forward.
